results.title: Balloon Incident Reveals More Than Spying as Competition With China Intensifies
results.abstract: There is nothing new about superpowers spying on one another, even from balloons. But for pure gall, there was something different this time.

results.title: An Even Deadlier Pandemic Could Soon Be Here
results.abstract: Bird flu has spread widely among animals. Unless we act now, it soon could do the same among humans.

results.abstract: Beijing registered “strong discontent and protest.” But there may be little it can do to retaliate.

results.adx_keywords: Missing Persons;Skull (Body Part);DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid);Genealogy;Forensic Science;Sotherden, Gary Frank;Clay (NY);Alaska
results.title: Skull Found in Alaska Is Linked to New York Man Missing Since 1976
results.abstract: Alaskan investigators used genetic testing and genealogy to connect a skull found in 1997 to a Clay, N.Y., man who had been missing for decades. Officials believe the man was likely mauled by a bear.

media.caption: A hunter found a human skull near the Porcupine River in Alaska in 1997. Investigators recently determined it was the remains of Gary Frank Sotherden, who was last seen in the area in 1976.

results.byline: By Helene Cooper and Edward Wong
results.title: U.S. Navy Divers Work to Recover Debris From Chinese Spy Balloon as Diplomacy Dwindles
results.abstract: The effort off the coast of South Carolina is expected to take days, and Navy and Coast Guard ships have been sent to the scene. U.S. officials are watching for retaliation from China.

media.caption: The shooting down of the spy balloon capped a remarkable week of high-stakes international drama.

results.abstract: The brutal nature of the mass shooting, which included the murder of an innocent young mother and her infant, shocked the nation.

results.title: Attacks on Electrical Substations Raise Alarm
results.abstract: After recent attacks caused thousands of people to lose power in Washington State and North Carolina, experts and legislators are calling for tighter security. And the F.B.I. is offering rewards.

results.title: A Patient Declared Dead Is Found in a Body Bag Gasping for Air

results.title: Gary Glitter Is Released From Prison After Serving Half of His Sentence
results.abstract: The disgraced former glam rock singer was found guilty in 2015 of sexually abusing three young girls in the 1970s. He had been given a 16-year sentence.

media.caption: Paul Gadd, better known by his stage name, Gary Glitter, arrived at court in London in 2015. He has been released after spending eight years in prison.

results.title: Harry Whittington, Texas Lawyer Shot by Cheney, Dies at 95
results.abstract: He drew headlines across the world when, during a hunting trip, he was accidentally blasted in the face and torso by Vice President Dick Cheney — then apologized himself for the incident.

media.caption: A bruised Harry Whittington spoke outside the hospital in Corpus Christi, Texas, where he was treated for his wounds after being shot by Vice President Dick Cheney in February 2006.
